Sunday 21
2 am arrived in Houston A  - ? of St.Jacinto?. There has been very heavy rains in the ?  Earths? full & roads bad - Sp do any be a wash or might off - we may have to taken oxen instead of horses for carriages.
Now the prairies to bottom of rivers from 60 to 70 feet ? sea level ? from it to back of Sept? 12 to 15 at ? 30 ? in barge?

Wednesday 24
? arrived from Galvaston hungry? nearly all the San Antonio persons 23 in no. (except those who have died - about 12)& Van Ness who were entrusted? at the instigation of General Thompson the U.S. Minister & who brought them away with him in the U.S.S. Ship Mss "Bainbridge"

 Many? prisoners they delayed after P? Calhoun will be here by the next New York? from N. Orleans.

element_texts.text: drunk to get up. Another Indian had one side of his face painted red, the other black. Another all red. there were some finely limbed men & boys. The  ? I guess pretty good looking & having small feet & hands. This young one had on one of these shirts 5 small rings of iron not quite closed. One of the Young Men said " Me little drunk - Ushern much drunk, drunk a heap. Whiskey make Indian bad - wants to fight" Men & Women dressed the garments made of printed stuff  - from there  ? with the  ? they have many of the conveniences of life.

Previously & after this period the Comanches were friendly with White men (not including Mexicans).
In 1839 - 300 persons died of Yellow fever in Houston 1843. Only two persons died of fever- (bilious) Majority of diseases brought on by intemperance.

 Saturday 27

Had to get new? & larger hand wheels & a new tongue to carriage - After dinner left Houston- accomp'd a few miles by the Night? & a dozen of the friends - 6 miles good road but the 3 next ? heavy prairie, to Conifers? & Camped. Tent up cots, ? camp seals?

element_texts.text:
Friday 28th
A Sweep of Polish Jews of very bad character received 39 lashes with a cow-hide for robbery. there are still other such like inducements against him. Old Sam was petitioned for him, but it did not succeed - he had broken ? in U. States. Cow-hiding I think is more severe than cat o' nine tails - when administered with a strong hand.

 The general opinion here is for annexation & that Old Sam is now really for it also, & ?

? today inform us that We cannot cross. The Brazos hyte? up - saw few deer
M.G. 4 5 miles thought us to Kirk, on the rd of the Brazos ? - Camped. Met Mr. Tetch? who informed us that we shall have a tough job thro' the bottom & looked quite dismayed to see our caravan. ? & Pepper trees - ?? - Black beans - Cut - ? grapes - makes good preserves
Monday 29th
Mr. Tetch? going to Galveston Sent all our ? back - hired 4 Oxen 2X to drag us thru' the Slough progress OK passed a

? this is the first party, I believe, that has travelled with such comforts & conveniences we may require them, but we shall get on but slowly. our four oxen are seemingly sufficient, bit if we get into heavy woods our pic nic plans may be frustrated

                                                                                    Travelled 9 miles
                                                                                    Sunday 28

During night - Slight rain Wind varied S.W. & light Northern Very cloudy Turned off Manfields - to Breys? B. 5 miles - road only tolerable No scarcity of flys, mosquitos, 6 miles to ? the 'Fork' of Rd? - had dinner -- took the Rd to Richmond - for travellers

element_texts.text: passed ? or as ? joined about here. Large cotton wood - appointed to the Sycamore ? in ? prob: of the poplar tribe - Met Messrs. Gilbean, Culligan &c &c on their journey to N. Orleans via Galveston with ?Speare? from San Antonio. pack mules is thier plan & a good one travelling 40 miles per day - they intended going by San Felipe but the Brazos water so high that it would have been impossible to get thro' the bottom - ceossed to Richmond, it is well Situated in a bluffy prairie - this

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1034x1827, frames 3

element_texts.text:
fine plantation - corn, cotton & Sugar luxuriating - roads pretty bad. Of Pringle could only see the Omnibus in the many difficulties coming along. Waters of the Brazos rising - 8 miles to Richmond ferry. Waters high two yds wide & running a 6 ? mile current owing to heavy rains in the interior. plantations looking well & prettily situated - Weather fine & clear S.E. fresh breezes.
50 feet water in River & at low water rounded pebbles formed. Surface soil clay loam - Marly ? & then the Deluged ? with pebbles.

undulating - pastures good.
The Brazos being so high, the gullies in the prairie filled with 'back water'. Alligator goes of large size in these 'back waters' & other fish.

  Nelson? the Jew who got the 39 lashes in Houston helped us today with bottom, & came into our camp, having put up at a farm near us. he was Known at Richmond & made to stolen? - he says he is going to Matamores - there the Mexican frontier is a place of refuge for our

element_texts.text:
place is but of small account as yet. Met Mr. Sullivan - married a daughter of Mrs. Long who lives near here. Folks along the Brazos preparing for an overflow. In 1824 about a mile from Richmond there was a great fight between the Shoctaws & Carancahuas [Karankawas] & which the latter were badly whipped. The inhabitants of this place did not think very favorably of Mr. Maillard & his doings when assisting on the 'Richmond Telescope".

 Camped 3 miles from Richmond prairies high & somewhat

element_texts.text:
Tuesday 30
Very heavy dews during night, 4 miles to 1st Timber - counted 15 to 20 diff. flowers in the prairie & Papos? flower - some very pretty.
Wt. into a precious difficulty honey? swept in ? in croping a hollow of 1st Timber
I thought it was a ? case as it is a case of - serious dislocation - 10 miles across bend to 2nd Timber. The Waters high - & covering the path 2 feet deep - the prairie abouts here covered with large ayellow flowers- fine & clear & they PP haze?. Noticed a pink & white variety of Aroma (of the Mimosa Specu?

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1033x1819, frames 3

element_texts.text: a very long trip of it. The strong wind of last night dissipated all the damp air of yesterday & thus we had no dew -  8am Cloudy, 81º - Prairies begin to rise & near the timbers undulate a little  Bottoms sickly during overflow, but prairies I think are healthy -plenty deer in prairies but rather wild. By great good luck our drivers came back with oxen they had strayed 6 miles, & were not easily tracked on account of there being no dew - 9 am started 4 miles passed a creek had to head into

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1033x1827, frames 3

element_texts.text:
A number got bagged - had to take all baggage out - back water of Brazos 2 feet in road at One Tree camp - Blew hard from SC about Ten& noon & got under lee of some timber - for this ? we suffered much from mosquitos  ? as used in E. Indies meshed to layer for our Mosquitos
May 1.  Wednesday
First difficulty with oxen.  strayed during the night - the way to travel in with pack ? - & they require no corn ike horses - If going to a setting trip then light jersey waggons with Mules - Oxen son longours de bétes - We shall have

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1035x1819, frames 3

element_texts.text:
Thursday 2nd
Persecuted by mosquitoes during the night. Inferior soil – mainly loam good for bricks and rough pottery. 6 Miles came to cross road from San Felipe to Columbus. The road ? appears to go to Lehange   bears  N.W. for ? in [?]]. 3 miles to 1 branch of Berman, fine clear running waters. Thick from sulfur soil, reforms on a bed of white marly clay ? with ? pebbles & sand – unclear, faded rest of page

element_texts.text:
2 miles to Bendetts plantation overflowed - they talk of going west - having  been so sick last [[?].  2 miles more to Allens, he is a tanner & keeps 'Public house' his back mile is  merely a hammer to beat the ? of bark on a mark, purchased corn & dried beef - after hundred yards further got butter & milk, from a very pretty woman - something like Temera - crossed Allens creek  good water 1 1/2  miles re-crossed the same having left the San Felipe @ 1 mile back 
camped -

a delicate oder - Here is park like scenery - but as yet -  the only chateaux, are those of ?  -  Varieties of the Mimosa species  ?  white  2 red globular flowers - 
To "Swear like a trooper" is another simile - but in Texas case. To swear like a Bullock driver when bugged. It is the concentrate essence of blasphemy  -  Though in bottom bad had to go round - Tan scarlet had species of geranium - ? plant - & peach -

On our arrival within a mile of the ferry found that there

element_texts.text:
Main branch of the Bernard. N. Ford gravel bottom, but up and down deep quick sand Surface soil about here sandy. A land of never finer sand and few pebbles. We nearly had a spill in the River. 2 miles further came to another branch of the Bernard. 2 more camps. No mosquitoes & slept for the first time since leaving Houston.
Friday 3
3 miles brought to Edge of Columbus Timbers of Post oak. Found many new plants and flowers. The Nymphaea Alba are great beauty with

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1032x1819, frames 3

element_texts.text:
comes to indurated sand.  Water good - Six miles below this some time since was found the solid part of  fossil horn it measures 6 feet - What the entire length was with the hollow part it is difficult to say - in Montgomery Al. a similar horn was discovered
Sunday 5
Water belly deep in the Slough ? soil (sandy) beds of gravel.  indurated Sand at Columbus crossing - Went to Columbus - dined with Tors & Robson - river falling fast - ?

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1032x1827, frames 3

element_texts.text:
had been a rapid rise in the Colorady & was filling a Slough we had to pass - I found at swimming - went to a sentinel just by, found some acquaintances they state in that there is more than 6 feet of water over the road & it is very bad, that no wheeled vehicle had passed for a long time - Camped - Found two pretty women addicted to 'Swabbing' but they had the grace to confess it was not a ? accomplishment.
Saturday 4
River falling slowly - not much game about here - Wells about 30 & 40 ft - 15 ? through a mainly gravelly soil, then

? near the ? house of Paso Cabales
Mr Byrne has 2 ? at Lamar - Lamar appears to have advantages as a pork farm
? at Lamar 25 to 30 feet high - wells can be dry from 4 feet - good grass for cattle
32 Miles from Lamar to Goliad - To Carlos' Rancho on the San Antonio 28 miles - ? about there where ? for draught can be ?

element_texts.text:
of mules & horses from C. Christi for the Houston Market  
Monday 6
Broke up camp - got through Colorado bottom 1 mile - muddy but not bad & with an extra yoke of steers - ferried across bravely & kindly recieved by Mr Robson & Son -
Lamar to Refugio 18 Miles good wood  Some mesquit   Attempted 200 Times has been written 300 yards of Stone in 8 feet water -
Mr Byrne has 2 ? is still part of ?

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1021x1819, frames 3

element_texts.text:
top two lines unclear
bade us adieu & returned to Columbus.   We are now out of the Muddy part of the country & the miasma of the low lands & are regaled with Southern or Gulf breezes.  Camped  2 ½  miles more in a small prairie having good grass - No Mosquitos fresh S. breezes - but myriads of fire flies, like so many sparkling gems - caught some of them - It is a long fly & the inferior or hinder part can be illuminated at pleasure & of a brilliant bluish white color -
Travelled 10
Wednesday 8th
Mg fine & air cool - a ? not like the coast & bottom

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1021x1827, frames 3

element_texts.text:
We can take advantage of houses for our Emigrants at Lamar -
Get Lavalles His. of Mexico for early history of Texas
Tuesday 7th
12 miles up the river, sandstone is found there enough for Grindstones - & occasionally used for building - Got Omnibus repaired 
Nos vamos a paso de cangtejo after dinner left Columbus over prairies & ? post oak rides - ground covered with good grass and now & then thick beds of marygold - the small geranium continues - 6 miles to ? Ck dry 1 1/2 more to

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1042x1819, frames 3

element_texts.text:
Today met with 8 or 19 New sorts of Prairie flowers some were beautiful.  Camped 2 miles ? about head of Mexican OK ? -
Thursday 9th
We are now on the Main Rd, having the 'Settlements' on our left - Water Lily in great abundance & beauty in Water holes & heads of Creeks - (Kowampopin Indian for Water Lily).  Around on the ? 8 to 9 miles from camp - There is no scarcity of snakes about but the plant cotton rattlesnake Master is in great abundance the root is ? - It has the taste of a strong bitter ?

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1042x1827, frames 3

element_texts.text:
Lands we have come from.
2 miles- came to another log 
house - full of girls & boys at
school.  1 to Townsends. 7 to 1st
Navidad 1/3 mile to 2nd- 1 mile to
fork & 4 to Shad Owens - 18 to LaVaca
30 to Gonzales - Cotton wood or
Canadian poplar- Navidad
R. sand bottoms with few pebbles 
got a bad strain with the
Bass - cracked & otherways
damaged the old wound in
fording or more properly in
getting up the bank. 1 Mile
to 2nd branch - here we had to
McAdamize - 6 miles to 
Rocky Ck sandstone clear water  
pretty undulating prairies
in the Post Oak timbers

element_texts.text:
leading up the river - ? course & took up on ? trail bearing S.W. travelled along it 6 or 7 miles to Pontons Ck ? when came across a road running E & W.  Mr. G. considered it the best to take.  ? Turkey, deer & saw two droves of Mustangs took on wood & water & camped 2 ½  miles on the prairie.  all the gallons have sprig water in them - 
Friday 10th
When taking the middle watch heard the howl of droves of wolves - good black surface soil  white aroma interspersed & four quakes upon sandstone undulating flowery prairies with ? hunting on the margins of creeks - ? is lands of timber - 5 miles by a last line unclear

element_texts.text:
country gone over, undulating prairies with groves of post oak - myrtle -

  Land of the myrtle, a cactus vine & Land of the brave & the free Joy around thee, for ever ?  Hail Goddess of sweet Liberty

Wild Hemp - oats - rye here  Francois & Dick - left hunting deer & turkey after what they considered something more interesting - when lo & behold a skunk discharged a large quantity of its fetid matter in Francois face - Dick got a touch of it - they stripped & washed in a water hole but we have to keep to windward of them - Crossed the LaVaca where I got lost last year took a right ? but found it

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1025x1819, frames 3

element_texts.text:
before Mr. Tilleys settlement on Mustang Ck (between Smithers & Brushy - tired & fatigued - put up for the night -
Saturday 11
Mr. T accompd me to ? the ground we camped yesterdy (about 12 Miles dist) no appearance of my party - went with him to Smithers Ck. to ? prior whenever a party goes on to the Abozos abgonzales - My party appeared to be on the Lubada trail by a fire I aw in the ?

  It appears that we should have taken the right hand rd

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1025x1827, frames 3

element_texts.text: a summit of the 'Big Hill' range & had a view of the beautiful woodlands - changed course to Southward - The gullies as they descend to N.W. look like white cliffs - (the result of the Limestone rock of the interior) few? on hills - numberless flowers - 4 miles t noon - plenty deer but wild (Elis S Hankins - Kind regards to Hays - Mrs Henry.  Mustang Ck.)  After dinner thought I saw a road to the left - seperated from my party - got upon a creek which I took for Ponton's - good water & wood - night came on, & after travelling 8 or 10 miles came

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1032x1819, frames 3

element_texts.text:
in back ? from Daniels in the LaNaca, & on N side with the Sagrays ? - ? hog & corn doings - weak coffee & no sugar - A sort of Indian looking country - camped at Thorns Ck 1 mile Sandstone - clear water
4 Miles to Brockhan's on Poach Ck 10 to Gonzalez thro post oaks - very hot - Some 3 or 4 miles back discovered the trail of our Waggon - & on arrival at G. found that they had arrived last night having got to a Settlement & then up the river - There a three men to be indicted for Murder tomorrow! -

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, aspect ratio, density 1x1, segment length 16, baseline, precision 8, 1032x1827, frames 3

element_texts.text:
after crossing the LaNaca at Daniels ford - or the one we crossed 5 or 6 from the LaNaca - My party ? strike around on the the Guadalupe & then go up to Gonzales - by the Cuero rd -Met Mr Smithers now an old man, gave me many anecdotes &c of the state of Texas some 20 years since.   
Mush & Milk for supper -
Sunday 12 -
Started with Mr Smith & two others for Gonzales - 10 m to Pontors Ck 2 miles came to our old Camp - & 4 more near the top of Big ?  Saw our trail where we turned off - Looking in the direction of the Cuero Rd saw mother of two fawns - prob signals for me - 4 miles to top of Big Hill;  ? we got up fell

element_texts.text:
Monday 13th
Ferried over Guadalupe - Got ? stock of Bacon & corn at Mr DeWitts - 8 cents bacon 3 ? corn - Corn is sent to San Antonio to be ground for Gonzales!? 8 miles having passed a dry prairie - Thick surface soil of a pretty good quality ? resting on a Sandstone - Selenite in loose pieces at ? - Mesquite - timbers 6 miles more & camped in the Post oaks - deer in plenty - No Scarcity of skunks &  rattle snakes - Noon 82º - 14 m  17 1/2
Tuesday 14 - 12
? Ft Galveston there has been a Succession of S.E. winds then are grateful indeed during the heat of the day - As ? much talk of indians about
